meanings.def: metal in the form of thin thread; a piece of this
examples: a coil of copper wire
wire mesh
A high wire fence encircles the complex.
a wire basket
The box was fastened with a rusty wire.
Cool the cakes on a wire rack.
Surely the wires shouldn't show like that?
The wire was stretched between two poles.
wire coat hangers

meanings.def: a piece of wire that is used to carry an electric current or signal
examples: electrical wires
a spider's web of unsightly overhead wires
The telephone wires had been cut.
Don't place carpets over electrical wires.
Don't touch that wire. It's live.
He disconnected the wire from the clock.
The electrician ran a wire from the kitchen to the bedroom.
The wire was attached to a pin in the plug.
Watch out for bare wires.
overhead electricity wires
the flow of electrical current down a wire
I found myself tripping over a tangle of wires and cables.
There were wires trailing everywhere.
Where does this wire go?

meanings.def: an electronic listening device that can be hidden on a person
examples: an undercover police informer who was wearing a wire
Three prisoners escaped by crawling under the wire.
Behind the wire, the prisoners were exercising.
They cut the perimeter wire and escaped.

meanings.def: a telegram (= a message sent by telegraph and then printed and given to somebody)
examples: We sent a wire asking him to join us.

meanings.def: to become confused about what somebody has said to you so that you think they meant something else
examples: We seem to have got our wires crossed. I thought you were coming on Tuesday.

meanings.def: if you say that a situation goes down to the wire, you mean that the result will not be decided or known until the very end
a person who is lively and full of energy
to use your influence in order to get an advantage for somebody
at the last possible opportunity; just in time
examples: The files arrived just under the wire and we made the deadline.
We got in under the wire.

idioms.def: to become confused about what somebody has said to you so that you think they meant something else
examples: We seem to have got our wires crossed. I thought you were coming on Tuesday.

idioms.idiom: go, come, etc. (right) down to the wire
idioms.def: if you say that a situation goes down to the wire, you mean that the result will not be decided or known until the very end
a person who is lively and full of energy
to use your influence in order to get an advantage for somebody

meanings.def: to connect a building, piece of equipment, etc. to an electricity supply using wires
examples: Make sure the plug is wired up correctly.
Many homes were wired for lighting only.
The Christmas tree lights are all wired to one plug.
You should check that the socket is correctly wired.

meanings.def: to connect somebody/something to a piece of equipment
examples: In the test, volunteers were wired up to brain monitors.
You can wire speakers to a flat-screen TV.
The microphone was wired to a loudspeaker.
She was wired up to a heart monitor.

meanings.def: to put a special device somewhere in order to listen secretly to other people’s conversations
examples: The room had been wired for sound.

meanings.def: to send somebody a message by telegram
examples: wire something (to somebody) He wired the news to us.
wire somebody (something) He wired us the news.

meanings.def: to send money from one bank to another using an electronic system
examples: wire something (to somebody) The bank wired the money to her.
wire somebody something The bank wired her the money.

meanings.def: to join things together using wire
examples: The components have to be wired together in a certain way.
